Early Access Review
It's time to break a little bad.Basement is a drug empire strategy game which is currently available through Steam Early Access. In Basement your aim is to create a successful drug empire by building facilities to produce drugs and taking over drug selling business to sell your product. But tread lightly, the larger your business grows the more attention you will attract from the police who will attempt to raid your facilities unless you 'persuade' them otherwise.I'm not in the meth business. I'm in the empire business.A word of warning, Basement, in its current stage, is more of a proof of concept than a game as most of the planned features are not present in the game yet. Despite the lack of content I, as a huge fan of Breaking Bad, enjoyed my time playing the game and look forward to seeing it develop. My review will be updated as and when this game is updated.+Awesome pixel-art style+Simple building mechanics, similar to XCOM or Smooth Operators+Four different types of drugs which can be produced using science, b**ch!+You can order your employees to attack the other businesses in the area and take control of them, you are the one who knocks+Your products are automatically collected from your base of operations to be delivered to your distributors+Taking over other facilities gets gradually more difficult as you get further away from your base of operations+The devs have set up a trello board so you can track their progress and they seem to be pretty active on the Steam forums, they're also very friendly+Good AI+Character descriptions are rather amusing+Nice soundtrack+Randomly generated cities-As mentioned there's not much to it, I won't mention everything and most of it can be discounted since it's Early Access but the main things are there's no tutorial so you have to learn for yourself and there's no objective other than make money -No way of speeding up timeVerdict:8An interesting strategy game with an awesome art style, simple mechanics and a good variety of products that is somewhat let down by its lack of content. If you're a fan of Breaking Bad this is not one to miss out on.***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***El K.

Early Access Review
								Ah! Nothing like waking up to the aroma of meth cooking in the morning!The Good Fun. Hiding from cops while cooking up all sorts of nefarious product in underground labs is delightfully entertaining Straightforward UI. There's no tutorial (or at least not one that I found), but its pretty easy to just sit down and GO. Graphics / Artwork. It feels a bit dodgy and run down, almost like graffiti art people, which is appropriate considering the subject matter. The minion AI isn't stupid. For the most part, it does precisely what it should be doing at a particular moment. Creepy music that I think works for a game like thisThe Bad No save-game? Seriously? I realize that they're probably trying to prevent players from saving before raids and then loading if they fail, but what if I have conquered the sandbox and want to play again, but don't want to throw away my awesome conquest? Super easy. I was able to beat it pretty-much the first time I picked it up. The strategy is very straightforward. If you don't have a line of junkies spilling out onto the street, and nobody dies, the police don't show up. Its all about managing that flow. Once its managed, the game becomes simple, and you can start training your conquest armies in peace. Overflowing money. Towards the endgame, you have too much money and nothing to buy. Part of this is because the money-stashes only hold $1000. When I beat the sandbox, there were whole houses that were nothing but money stashes because the game nags at you irritatingly every time you get money but have nowhere to put it. I am playing this during early access, so take these with a grain of salt, but there are some bugs. The delivery trucks didn't work for me. They would get to a place and stop and then never move again. The controls are also a bit finnicky when it comes to assigning workers to rooms.Suggestions Guns would be good. Considering the subject matter, I don't think devs need to worry about violence influencing children Competing drug labs would also be good. It might be fun to try and get the cops to go after them, as well as bust up their operations yourself There's no real difference in the drugs aside from market value. I would have liked some kind of tangential side effect, like Acid-takers tripping out and becoming erratic, pot smokers becoming mellow, speed users getting into more fights (etc) I think it would also be more fun if there were a bonus to providing a selection of substances, rather than really just wanting to provide the most expensive one.ConclusionGood game already. I have high hopes for the final product being even better!  :)

								I'm not going to do a typical review, because other people have already discussed the pros and cons of the game's intent, design, and execution.What I would like to review is the community's quickness to disparage indie developers and jump on the abandonware paranoia bandwagon. Games take a long time to develop. Especially with an independent studio that is oft times relying on money coming in to pay the few employees, or purchase assets.Decide for yourselves if a game is something you're interested in, and would be willing to support...but please don't shoot us all in the foot by writing a hundred reviews where you cavalierly play the role of Chicken Little and kill a game's chances before it has even had time to develop.This game went a few months without an update.And...people lost their minds.Have any of you played The Long Dark? It has been in EA since before dirt was invented. They may go months without updates. But when they do update, it is significant. It improves the game. It makes it more playable. I have gotten more value out of playing TLD, and replaying after each update than any major-studio release in my library. It is one of my most cost-effective purchases, ever, in the realm of entertainment.With EA, you toss your money in the hat and enjoy a sneak peak at potential greatness in a genre or niche that you find interesting. You check on it when it updates, and take the journey along with the rest of the community that supports it. Please understand, though, that if you jump the gun and shoot down a game you briefly believed in, because your paranoia made you think it was abandoneware - you're potentially screwing all of us out of a completed game. It is a self-fulfilling prophecy.I understand that some EA games do fizzle out. Some developers do take the money and run. It happens. But if you believe in a game, give the developer the benefit of the doubt. If you aren't willing to do that, then don't take a gamble on Early Access in the first place.TL;DR: This game's review score was tanked by irresponsible Chicken Little spazzes who wrote tons of reviews calling the game dead, after a few months without an update. Then, the developer comes out with their huge level editor tool, and progress update - but they've already lost months' worth of potential capital that could've helped further refine the game, because $9 is worth wetting yourself over, apparently. Most of said spazzes still have not revised their reviews, and so continue to incorrectly slander a developer that has absolutely proved them wrong.

Early Access Review
								[Note: This is one of those times when a 'maybe' button would be useful - see explanation at the bottom in regards to the negative review.]Basement is, in a nutshell, a reversed Sim Tower meets Breaking Bad. As of the current release, you play an unnamed scientist with the aim of bringing the entire city/urban area/whatever it is under your control. The game is bare bones right now, and goes something like this:- Build new drug labs/security checkpoints.- Hire new chemists/henchmen.- Send henchmen to neighboring buildings to take them over: be prepared to send two or three truckloads, as they tend to die in rather short order.- Send henchmen back to previously conquered locations to fight off police raids (or bribe them if you're making money hand over fist)- Take over every building on the map; you win!The game is lacking in content at the moment - my playtime represents a single game start to finish, with the only replay value being in the randomly generated maps. You have a very small selection of room choices and no upgrades or real variety for your chemists and henchmen (beyond very small stat changes that are tied in to the hiring cost/upkeep of them). On the plus side, the developers seem on the ball with patches and rolling out content, so this should be remedied sooner rather than later.However, I can't recommend it at this time - I think more than a few people would be disappointed by the lack of content for the price. If you want to support the developers, buy it, play it for a bit, and shelve it until you start seeing updates. If you're on the fence, or just know that you'd rather purchase it in a more complete state - just put it on your wishlist and come back in three months.

Early Access Review
								So far, this game seems...Alright.Very little content so far but that's to be expected. I hope the developer adds more rooms, more things to sell, and makes the products more unique. The game seems to lack "end game" content, i.e., what is there left to do when you take control and can successfully defend from cops? There should be some high end facilities you can get.Two things I would suggest:There should be bonuses for good room placement. What I mean by that is, say, if you have two storage rooms next to each other, they should connect and be able to hold slightly more. If you have two grow boxes next to each other, maybe they could connect and make a hydroponics lab, which means the production rate gets +.2 or something like that. I think this would make designing your buildings much more interesting. Maybe larger rooms could require a little more power to balance it out?And a more major thing: The game needs to be more forgiving in the beginning. For example, I spent 15 minutes sloooowly expanding so I didn't draw the immediate attention of cops, and then my dealer had to take a break. He came back and got murdered by an angry customer. There was literally nothing I could do about this, because my dealer spawned with low health.Anyway, the game is playable, but not quite enjoyable yet. I'll come look again in a couple months perhaps.p.s. This game is a little more suggestion centered than review centered, but A. this is in early access and the dev needs feedback and B. theres so little content that you've played the entire game if you've watched the trailer.

								Pretty good for a Breaking Bad simulator!All joking aside, it's a shockingly fun little strategy game for what they have so far. You play as a fledgling drug cartel building his empire in a randomly generated district, and are tasked with juggling your funds as you hire cooks, bodyguards, and deal with the police through either fighting or bribing, both of which become harder as your empire becomes bigger. You also have to manage the comfort and health of your employees, because if they get too tired, their productivity/fighting skill goes down, which hurts you in the wallet. It's surprisingly polished for being in the early stages, which is more than can be said for other games that have been released in early access. Ironically it reminds me of those edutainment games I used to play in middle school like Lemonade Stand, as it is at its core a business simulator. My hopes for future updates are more/different drug choices, better ways to manage your employees, and more fighting/building options (and being able to build things in empty cells would be nice hint hint). I also heard Quests were coming soon, so that's worth looking forward to.Definitely worth the 8 bucks imo, now that the latest update added saving.

Early Access Review
								Edited review.Basement is a fun management game that puts you in the shoes of a drug dealer attempting to expand his empire in an urban setting.Although still in Early Access, it is fairly playable in its current state, with each subsequent update seemingly focused on extending the game's already considerable playability further.The game requires you to acquire buildings to setup your operations and hire staff to manufacture and distribute your product (as well as hiring muscle to protect it). In addition, you must keep up with the demand of junkies, while diversifying in what drugs you make/sell. This increases your revenue, enabling you to acquire new buildings and expand your empire further, but also makes your business more prone to police raids.Buying transport to transport goods between premises is an option provided you have a garage, providing further depth to your manufacturing and distribution network, and forcing you to think about designating premises to perform particular functions: manufacture, distribution, storage etc.Each character in the game has a set of stats which indicates things attributes such as: health, damage, ability to sell drugs, ability to manufacture etc. which level up over time as the attribute is used. This enables you to specialise your employees in order to maximise their effectiveness at their given tasks.Aesthetically the game's pixel graphics are well-done and quite charming in their presentation. The minimal soundtrack compliments the atmosphere and immersion the chosen pixel art style affords, and I look forward to future updates that expand out the content even further.At the moment the game is currently only a sandbox mode, but the developer has mentioned future updates will also include other traditional game modes.Should you buy the game now in its current state, you will get something that is currently playable, but will also be contributing to its further enhancement which is en exciting prospect given how fun it already is.Lets just hope the updates keep coming :)

								Edited review.Basement is a fun management game that puts you in the shoes of a drug dealer attempting to expand his empire in an urban setting.Although still in Early Access, it is fairly playable in its current state, with each subsequent update seemingly focused on extending the game's already considerable playability further.The game requires you to acquire buildings to setup your operations and hire staff to manufacture and distribute your product (as well as hiring muscle to protect it). In addition, you must keep up with the demand of junkies, while diversifying in what drugs you make/sell. This increases your revenue, enabling you to acquire new buildings and expand your empire further, but also makes your business more prone to police raids.Buying transport to transport goods between premises is an option provided you have a garage, providing further depth to your manufacturing and distribution network, and forcing you to think about designating premises to perform particular functions: manufacture, distribution, storage etc.Each character in the game has a set of stats which indicates things attributes such as: health, damage, ability to sell drugs, ability to manufacture etc. which level up over time as the attribute is used. This enables you to specialise your employees in order to maximise their effectiveness at their given tasks.Aesthetically the game's pixel graphics are well-done and quite charming in their presentation. The minimal soundtrack compliments the atmosphere and immersion the chosen pixel art style affords, and I look forward to future updates that expand out the content even further.At the moment the game is currently only a sandbox mode, but the developer has mentioned future updates will also include other traditional game modes.Should you buy the game now in its current state, you will get something that is currently playable, but will also be contributing to its further enhancement which is en exciting prospect given how fun it already is.Lets just hope the updates keep coming :)

Well as relaxing as a drug cooking and dealing game can be...-Replayability. It is decently replayable. I am not going to replay the game 50 more times and waste 100 hours of my life on it (at least not until they update it again) but still decently replayable.Cons-Repetative. Early Access Review
								My thoughts on this game are mixed. I would recommend it, but I would wait for it to go on sale before you buy it. Eight dollars is not much and when it goes on sale you can get it for a pretty low price. The game is a lot of fun, but is somewhat low on content. There is a "campaign mode" that is six missions long, but there is no overarching story to them, and they are more like a series of scenarios that you can play. They ramp up in difficulty as they go on. There is also an endless mode. The gameplay is a lot of fun, and kept me engaged throughout the whole game. Each of the scenarios are fun and provide an interesting new thing to do in the game. For example one scenario has you in a prison where you can't hire people. Instead you get new workers by taking over cell blocks. I enjoy the graphics of the game. Also the game had no problems running on my computer which is now especially getting quite out of date. I never had any problems with long loading times, or lag. The interface in the game is very intuitive, and is easy to use. The game is also easy to learn, and can be simple, but also has some features that provide some more complexity, so the game is great if you want to play it casually or more seriously. So far everything that I have said has been pretty positive, but there are some negative aspects to this game. First off the game has a lack of content, only six missions and an endless mode won't take you long to beat. I have beaten the game twice and have about 7 hours of playtime, as of writing this review. There has been a while since an update to the game, and it seems that the devs are not putting a lot of time into developing the game further. This is why I can't recommend the game at the full eight dollars especially if you have a tight game budget. The other negative thing that I have to say about the game is that there are some unfair game mechanics. One feature of the game is that the police will come and raid you occasionally. When they arrive they will give you an option, you can fight them or can bribe them to go away without a fight. I think there has been a total of one or two times where I have been able to pay off the bribe. Even when I have a lot of money I can't pay it off and that can be a bit frustrating because the police can kill a lot of your workers or even fully take over your main base. You can avoid this risk by having a person that has very good fighting stats in your base. However it was still frustrating when it happened. Other than this most of the gameplay features are balanced. The gangs in the final mission can sometimes kill you very early in the game before you have a real time to set up which was again frustrating. However even considering this bit of frustration that I had the gameplay of Basement was very fun and I found myself wanting to try the mission again, or immediately planning how I can take back my base from the police or bring it back to its former glory. PROS-Good Graphical Style -Fun Gameplay-Good Strategy-Mostly Bug Free (I haven't encountered any, but I don't want to say it is completely bug free)-Will run on pretty much any computerCONS-Lack of Content-Some Unfair Gameplay-Devs may have abandoned the gameOverall I would recommend the game. It is a ton of fun to play, but it has a lack of content. If you buy it buy it when it is on sale. Considering the amount of content that is in it right now it not worth the eight dollar price tag. Hopefully the devs will continue developing the game, and it does not get stuck in early access hell.
